Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Impacted residents, many of whom are older, have disabilities and bought their homes decades ago, have experienced a range of difficult emotions as they’ve been displaced in recent months and watched their community dramatically change due to the land movement.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: In February, Rancho Palos Verdes Mayor John Cruikshank said a state of emergency declaration from the governor would allow them to bypass state permit requirements for repair efforts.
“The land movement has created a dangerous situation, and Edison is deciding to disconnect to keep that community safe,” said Jim Hanggi, a spokesperson for the utility.
Leon said he and his neighbors are just trying to "figure out how to survive.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Leon told LAist he plans to move into a tiny home on his property and bought four generators to power it. He said he’s had no gas for weeks now, but water is still running. The power in his house has been shut off indefinitely, so his plan is to move off the grid.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Leon doesn't want to leave his neighborhood because he loves its beauty and that he gets to look at the ocean every day, he said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We’re hearing that our residents want to stay in their homes, and we're doing everything we can to keep them in their homes,” Cruikshank said.
“We're going to do everything we can to push the governor and the federal government to provide them funds.”

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Tuesday declared a state of emergency for the city of Rancho Palos Verdes "to protect public safety amid ongoing land movement that has resulted in disrupted utility services and evacuation warnings for impacted residents."
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Tuesday declared a state of emergency for the city of Rancho Palos Verdes

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: A spokesperson for Southern California Edison on Monday said the power outages will impact some homes longer than others: They say 20 will be without power indefinitely and 38 will be without power for one to three weeks.
